unnormalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey Through Ayurveda in Kerala
normalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey Through Ayurveda in Kerala

unnormalised: I've always been drawn to the idea of holistic wellness, especially the ancient wisdom of Ayurveda. So, when the opportunity arose to spend two weeks in Kerala, "God's Own Country," at an Ayurvedic retreat, I jumped at it. I'd heard so much about the transformative power of these treatments, and honestly, I was feeling a bit depleted – the constant hustle of city life in Mumbai was taking its toll.
normalised: I've always been drawn to the idea of holistic wellness, especially the ancient wisdom of Ayurveda. So, when the opportunity arose to spend two weeks in Kerala, "God's Own Country," at an Ayurvedic retreat, I jumped at it. I'd heard so much about the transformative power of these treatments, and honestly, I was feeling a bit depleted – the constant hustle of city life in Mumbai was taking its toll.

unnormalised: My destination was a small, family-run retreat nestled amidst the lush green hills near Munnar. The day began early, usually around 06:00 hrs, with gentle yoga and meditation overlooking the tea plantations. Then came the consultation with Dr. Priya, a warm and incredibly knowledgeable Ayurvedic practitioner. She took my pulse, asked about my lifestyle and habits, and determined my *dosha* imbalance – a Vata imbalance, apparently!
normalised: My destination was a small, family-run retreat nestled amidst the lush green hills near Munnar. The day began early, usually around six hundred hours, with gentle yoga and meditation overlooking the tea plantations. Then came the consultation with Doctor Priya, a warm and incredibly knowledgeable Ayurvedic practitioner. She took my pulse, asked about my lifestyle and habits, and determined my *dosha* imbalance – a Vata imbalance, apparently!

unnormalised: The treatments were personalized based on Dr. Priya's assessment. For 9 days, I received daily *abhyanga* (oil massage), followed by *shirodhara* (warm oil poured on the forehead) which was strangely relaxing, even though the thought of oil dripping on my face initially unnerved me. I also underwent *pizhichil*, a full-body treatment with medicated oils. The aroma of the oils – sandalwood, jasmine, and something earthy I couldn't quite place – filled the air and instantly calmed my senses.

unnormalised: Initially, the strict diet – primarily vegetarian and tailored to pacify Vata – was a challenge. No spicy street food like I'm used to back in Mumbai! But slowly, I began to appreciate the simple, nourishing meals. I even learned a few recipes from the retreat's cook, Aunty Lakshmi.

unnormalised: There were moments of doubt, of course. "Is this really working?" I wondered on day 4. But by the end of my stay on 20/03/2023, I felt a noticeable shift. My sleep improved, my digestion was better, and I felt a deep sense of calm. I even managed to wake up at 05:30 hrs one morning without an alarm – unheard of for me!

unnormalised: It wasn't a magic bullet, and maintaining the benefits requires conscious effort back home. But my Ayurvedic journey in Kerala has given me the tools – and the motivation – to prioritize my well-being. I plan to revisit on 15/11/2024 for another round of rejuvenation. And maybe, just maybe, learn to make perfect *masala chai* like Aunty Lakshmi.
